articles.headline: In Texas Jobs Boom, Crediting a Leader, or Luck
articles.snippet: Some economists and skeptics of Gov. Rick Perry of Texas said the flourishing oil and gas industry — not his political leadership — had kept the state afloat.
articles.abstract: Some economists and skeptics of Gov. Rick Perry of Texas said the flourishing oil and gas industry — not his political leadership — had kept the state afloat.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Texas is home to at least one-third of the jobs created nationwide since the recession ended. The state’s economy is growing about twice as fast as the national rate. Home prices have remained stable even as much of the country has seen sharp declines.

articles.headline: Debt in Europe Fuels a Bond Debate
articles.snippet: Many analysts say that the euro zone may have no choice but to issue bonds if it wants to keep the currency union from falling apart.
articles.abstract: Many analysts say that the euro zone may have no choice but to issue bonds if it wants to keep the currency union from falling apart.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The Germans want to bury it. The French say it is a nonstarter. But the idea that the only way to contain the sovereign debt crisis is for Europe to issue bonds backed by all the nations of the euro zone will not go away.

articles.headline: A Closer Look at Taxes on the Rich
articles.snippet: Warren E. Buffett, the billionaire investor, called on Congress to raise taxes on the wealthy, pushing the issue to the forefront of the debate of the growing budget deficit.
articles.abstract: Warren E. Buffett, the billionaire investor, called on Congress to raise taxes on the wealthy, pushing the issue to the forefront of the debate of the growing budget deficit.
articles.lead_paragraph: With the budget deficit growing and tax rates at a 60-year low, one question will remain near the center of the political debate in the coming months: Should the federal government raise taxes on the rich?

articles.headline: On Wide Florida Roads, Running for Dear Life
articles.snippet: The Orlando-Kissimmee region was first out of 52 in the rankings of most dangerous pedestrian regions, with more than 550 pedestrians killed from 2000 to 2009.
articles.abstract: The Orlando-Kissimmee region was first out of 52 in the rankings of most dangerous pedestrian regions, with more than 550 pedestrians killed from 2000 to 2009.
articles.lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — As any pedestrian in Florida knows, walking in this car-obsessed state can be as tranquil as golfing in a lightning storm. Sidewalks are viewed as perks, not necessities. Crosswalks are disliked and dishonored. And many drivers maniacally speed up when they see someone crossing the street.

articles.headline: Google’s Coup Shifts Mobile Alliances
articles.snippet: Despite reassurances from Google that it will run Android as an open platform, some fear former partners will become rivals.
articles.abstract: Despite reassurances from Google that it will run Android as an open platform, some fear former partners will become rivals.
articles.lead_paragraph: Major telephone makers like Samsung, HTC, Sony Ericsson and LG said on Monday that they supported Google’s planned purchase of Motorola. But will they still feel that way in a year?

articles.headline: Nordstrom in New York to Use an Alias
articles.snippet: Instead of opening its first department store in New York City, Nordstrom is testing the waters with a charitable concept store called Treasure & Bond.
articles.abstract: Instead of opening its first department store in New York City, Nordstrom is testing the waters with a charitable concept store called Treasure & Bond.
articles.lead_paragraph: After flirting for years with a move into New York City, Nordstrom is opening a full-priced store in Manhattan. But the store will not have Nordstrom in its name, or even feel like a Nordstrom.

articles.headline: Europe’s Debt Crisis Weakens Quarterly Growth
articles.snippet: Europe’s sovereign debt crisis threatened to spill over into the broader economy as figures showed that growth in the euro zone fell to its lowest rate in two years.
articles.abstract: Europe’s sovereign debt crisis threatened to spill over into the broader economy as figures showed that growth in the euro zone fell to its lowest rate in two years.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Europe’s sovereign debt crisis threatened to spill over into the broader economy after official figures released Tuesday showed that growth in the euro zone fell to its lowest rate in two years. Germany — the Continent’s powerhouse — slowed almost to a standstill.

articles.headline: Retailers Glean Profit in Slow Sales
articles.snippet: Analysts said that chains were keeping inventories lean, using marketing dollars strategically and quickly marking down slow-moving items.
articles.abstract: Analysts said that chains were keeping inventories lean, using marketing dollars strategically and quickly marking down slow-moving items.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as worries grow about another economic downturn, major retail companies continue to report strong earnings, thanks to tough lessons from the recession.

articles.headline: Letter Counters Hacking Avowals From News Corp.
articles.snippet: The disclosures threatened to push the scandal back to the forefront of public concern, raising questions for Rupert Murdoch and the British prime minister, David Cameron.
articles.abstract: The disclosures threatened to push the scandal back to the forefront of public concern, raising questions for Rupert Murdoch and the British prime minister, David Cameron.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — An influential parliamentary committee investigating phone hacking at Rupert Murdoch’s now-defunct tabloid, The News of the World, released a potentially damning four-year-old letter Tuesday claiming that hacking was routine and “widely discussed” at the paper, a direct contradiction of repeated assertions by the paper’s owners and editors that until recently they were unaware of the breadth of the problem.

articles.headline: Court Sides With Trustee Over Madoff Payouts
articles.snippet: A federal appeals court decision is a setback for thousands of “net winners” in the vast fraud by Bernard L. Madoff.
articles.abstract: A federal appeals court decision is a setback for thousands of “net winners” in the vast fraud by Bernard L. Madoff.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court panel reviewing one of the fiercest legal disputes to arise from Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme ruled on Tuesday that the embattled trustee’s approach on how to calculate investor losses in the case is “legally sound” and fundamentally fair.
